abstract: HSBC Holdings said Monday it would consolidate two structured investment vehicles, or SIVs, bringing $45 billion of assets onto the British lender’s balance sheet. The move, which is expected to reduce the worldwide assets in SIVs, comes as United States banks are trying to organize an $80 billion fund to stabilize these kinds of vehicles.
lead_paragraph: HSBC Holdings said Monday it would consolidate two structured investment vehicles, or SIVs, bringing $45 billion of assets onto the British lender’s balance sheet. The move, which is expected to reduce the worldwide assets in SIVs, comes as United States banks are trying to organize an $80 billion fund to stabilize these kinds of vehicles.
